document.title: AP® Research Course and Exam Description, Effective Fall 2024

973839A1B7564E0B9E37C797DCFA8C9B.description:
Communities of scholars
produce, present, and perform effectively
when participants actively seek and
provide feedback.

0DD74E03BE424EFDA06432E981D5F58E.description:
Peer review is an effective way
for scholars to strengthen their critical
eye as well as strengthen their own work.

683C82C128F54FE4A3A08CDD2881D01B.description:
Engaging in peer review
to receive and consider responses
to their work.

F6F85D5BC3824509A794C73D19AB6A3B.description:
Peer review should be based
on guidelines and defined criteria
appropriate to the work.

9FF1A42A25DB4D0096F41C89D7105AC8.description:
Engaging in peer review to
provide constructive responses to
one another’s work, appropriate
to the stage of a project’s
development.

395C1FAFA1F447BEB58FFE9D44BE7F0B.description:
Scholars perform, present,
and/or produce their work within a
larger community. Throughout the
inquiry process, scholars interact
with and benefit from the scholarly
community through thoughtful
engagement with the opinions and
critiques of others.

EBB5468CF52945ED861F75713B37D64D.description:
Reflective scholars
acknowledge how their inquiry
processes and resulting works can
be transformational for their own and
others’ understanding as well as for their
personal identities as scholars.

B61688C82D2C4FC0BA2601801D506C7D.description:
Reflective scholars explore
potential future directions for their
inquiries and the development of their
own scholarship or bodies of work.

96B52B8F7B174A7F98F2CF7C5A6040CA.description:
Reflecting on the larger
significance of engaging in the
overall inquiry process and
producing a completed scholarly
work.

138F780043414EF1BBEDB795A3CDAB98.description:
Reflection acknowledges the
impact of actions on both the group
and individual contributions, noting the
reasons for such actions, assumptions
made, and whether or not such actions
and assumptions hindered or helped
the achievement of the group’s and
individuals’ tasks.

1C4C4031AB844689A3BDD1A7127EE3C3.description:
Reflecting on
experiences of collaborative
effort.

E07FD3668AB34CD1A32F06FEFD7BA534.description:
Scholars reflect on how the
inquiry process helped them deepen
their understanding, make important
connections, and develop greater
self-direction.

BEE8102811214D34BF2B2952D46C9FC6.description:
Scholars are mindful of the
rationale behind the chosen method for
data collection, information gathering,
analysis, production, and presentation.

86D5F3B72795412886933E7A8582F97E.description:
Learning requires practice
through an iterative process of thinking/
rethinking, vision/revision, and writing/
rewriting.

A4EC2249F98548BF8380D2744BA96CFE.description:
Reflection is an ongoing and
recursive process in inquiry, often leading
to changes in understanding. Strategies
for reflection may include journal writing,
self-questioning, drawing, exploration of
space, and/or guided contemplation.

A10FD4A5FFF847A099FA841F04F294DB.description:
Reflecting on and
revising their own writing, thinking,
and creative processes.

665A33FDDCEF4348ACE9BA7089BEAB87.description:
Reflection increases learning,
self-awareness, and personal growth
through identification and evaluation
of personal conclusions and their
implications.

1F148686B29B4FD084CECE6FCBC77982.description:
Effective teams consider the
use of online collaborative tools.

362535D1E49748F78D4F8F9EBC76BAA6.description:
Teams function at their
best when they practice effective
interpersonal communication, consensus
building, conflict resolution, and
negotiation.

FBE09932B62C43BFB4133D25B027FC80.description:
Teams function at their best
when they understand the diversity of
their social–cultural perspectives, talents,
and skills.

BC2D8A990E2845CAB8061BA28D38B1AB.description:
Teams are built around
tasks. Low-risk teambuilding activities
and simulations enhance a team’s
performance.

1B12DA54FB1F490C875E5A79DD7AEF80.description:
Fostering constructive
team climate, resolving conflicts,
and facilitating the contributions
of all team members to address
complex, open-ended problems.

CA794611053444ADB80BC67974710B55.description:
Knowing and communicating
one’s strengths and challenges to a
group allows one’s contributions to be
more effective.

7BC4D27E9A3F4BDA85614BF6FC7BD2A4.description:
Providing individual
contributions to overall
collaborative effort to accomplish
a task or a goal.

43EB9155543242C9B7D655B8429E8618.description:
Teams are most effective
when they draw on the diverse
perspectives, skills, and backgrounds
of team members to address
complex, open-ended problems.

925AF68E658E49819620801E8317EC7C.description:
Scholars engage thoughtfully
with their audiences’ critiques and
questions.

62657AE40B684E6487A1A191660B333D.description:
Scholars effectively articulate
the rationale for inquiry choices in
relation to the completed work.

3A1AD09BC31B44FB9682A885BDDBABD9.description:
Defending inquiry
choices and final product
with clarity, consistency, and
conviction.

76A83CAE2B8B4F888FA80341729E3768.description:
Scholars present, perform,
and/or produce their completed work
after multiple revisions or rehearsals (e.g.,
responding to audience feedback, selfcritique of recorded performance) and
polishing.

375A783052E0402EB4A2A73038543929.description:
Scholars present, perform,
and/or produce their work in multiple
ways. This may take discipline-specific
forms (e.g., portfolios, exhibits,
performances, showcases, premieres,
posters), but may also cross disciplinary
boundaries.

B5E59BE1866A4BFF813DAD1A6074FFE0.description:
Speakers vary elements of
delivery (e.g., volume, tempo, movement,
eye contact, vocal variety, energy) to
emphasize information, convey tone, and
engage their audience.

810D936B57E84265AEEE9F818E248D05.description:
Engaging an audience by
employing effective techniques of
delivery or performance.

6D1C9895F6C24635B49CE83045A8C842.description:
Scholars should articulate their
choices and content in a language that is
not discipline-specific to communicate
effectively to nonexperts or people
outside the discipline.

F465A84384FD4D07A79D4EBA247B44D9.description:
Arguments can be adapted by
strategically selecting and emphasizing
information considering audience,
situation, medium, and purpose.

23E5F37C1B4A4915BFC4F7BFAFC65C49.description:
Adapting an argument for
context, purpose, and/or audience.

F08F41A2A67342BDBB18306A18BDCC50.description:
Effective communication
requires choosing appropriate media
(e.g., essay, poster, oral presentation,
documentary, research report/thesis)
according to context, purpose, and
audience.

7DB4CBD3B83D43D5B2B55B0BE8817FD3.description:
Data and other information
can be presented graphically (e.g.,
infographics, graphs, tables, models)
to aid audience understanding and
interpretation.

0E3330A30B944234B9153323A3557667.description:
Effective organizational and
design elements (e.g., headings, layout,
illustrations, pull quotes, captions, lists)
may aid in audience engagement and
understanding by calling attention to
important information and/or creating
emotional responses in the audience.
Ineffective use or overuse of these
elements disrupts audience engagement
and understanding.

B2ED7C83F18A4663B90E8628B64B2F54.description:
Communicating
information through appropriate
media using effective techniques
of design.

F82705EA81AF4D368358618D149224A6.description:
Spelling and grammar errors
detract from credibility.

E97BBF9D51BD48D9BE663A5A9D60EEF8.description:
Precision in word choice
reduces confusion, wordiness, and
redundancy.

04F06A2F7E274029A4BB6131ED12D213.description:
Effective sentences create
variety, emphasis, and interest through
structure, agreement of elements,
placement of modifiers, and consistency
of tense.

E731180BDD934F00BBD03C94DF4B2AA4.description:
A writer expresses tone or
attitude about a topic through word
choice, sentence structure, and imagery.

E3D4B73D8E07451FB5300762F17BDE07.description:
Adhering to established
conventions of grammar, usage,
style, and mechanics.

C527A9B3A56E4FF0AF0B7A2D338821B4.description:
Coherence is achieved when
the elements and ideas in an argument
flow logically and smoothly. Transitions
are used to move the audience from one
element or idea to another by illustrating
the relationship between the elements
or ideas.

B1E816D1B9DF4EFFA660ABF44A2FA008.description:
Bibliography: provides a complete list
of sources cited and consulted in the
appropriate disciplinary style

21CD8746B4F34B9F8BC3B4707E35AE40.description:
Conclusion and Future Directions:
reflects on the process and how
this project could impact the field;
discusses possible next steps

09DC80C09FCF456DA382C8C7024A719C.description:
Discussion, Analysis, and/or
Evaluation: interprets the significance
of the results, product, or findings;
explores connections to original
research question/project goal;
discusses the implications and
limitations of the research or
 creative work

77F9DB94330F421AA3EE2134C0DEB54B.description:
Results, Product, or Findings:
presents the results, product,
evidence, or findings

C9F5C19A5F62477CB06A0227B3CAB71A.description:
Method, Process, or Approach:
explains and provides justification
for the chosen method, process, or
approach

354C403C2E054A4B86BDC51D31189BDB.description:
Introduction: provides background
and contextualizes the research
question/project goal, reviews
previous work in the field related to
the research question/project goal,
and identifies the gap in the current
field of knowledge to be addressed

8D6DCCB24BBE46E8B4EBDF9D69CD337B.description:
Inquiries result in
conclusions that can be presented in
different formats and that typically have
the following elements:

14BCAB6C23A74E45881E143B33C0F22E.description:
Planning and
producing a cohesive academic
paper, considering audience,
context, and purpose.

6D64BF6B69034D178F1340E997B26D29.description:
Conclusion: synthesizes reasoning,
considers possible implications
for the future, and ties back to the
introduction

7CADDE73E3C74C44A37DA67C582D09EC.description:
Counterargument, concession,
refutation, and rebuttal: acknowledge
and/or respond to opposing
arguments

47E30B93C1114F56BBECAE193B06B545.description:
Reasons, evidence, and commentary:
provide support for the argument

06B61928B4CE4E74979B1F68C2EE00DF.description:
Thesis: conveys the main idea of an
argument

B00182E9330A4022A4C5B91F733FEBE4.description:
Introduction: engages the audience
by providing background and/or
context

4B1E50A67ACF48058F207B550E004170.description:
An argument may include
the following elements:

82B820FB2F9C4FBEB99FDA971E225493.description:
Planning, producing,
and presenting a cohesive
argument, considering audience,
context, and purpose.

E2E93E4D913D44FA82A0FC6332767274.description:
How a perspective or
argument is presented affects how
people interpret or react to it. The
same perspective or argument may
be developed or presented differently
depending on audience, purpose, and
context.

FCC1A79282E64CF0B49C2F9B23C82036.description: Big Idea 5: Team, Transform, and Transmit

1996929DB11E4A4BBCA1067B5D0C5DE0.description:
When making choices and
proposing solutions, the advantages and
disadvantages of the options should be
weighed against the goal within its context.

64FD6B74E8F34C859AA27AFAC64F2F5A.description:
Offering resolutions,
conclusions, and/or solutions
based on evidence considering
limitations and implications.

069848A9C4D04345A212C84B25BD1F22.description:
Arguments, choices, and
solutions present intended and
unintended opportunities and
consequences.

94CD5E1AA9AA41E3957E468F72548F49.description:
Innovative solutions and
arguments identify and challenge
assumptions, acknowledge the importance
of content, imagine and explore alternatives,
and engage in reflective skepticism.

AB7646A5C867460282B3683683981531.description:
Extending an idea,
question, process, or product
to innovate or create new
understandings.

8D30C7A1CC6B42C08FFA19AA7FB1FD05.description:
Forming one’s own
perspective and reaching new
understandings involve innovative
thinking and synthesis of existing
knowledge with personally
generated evidence.

5897338E60C74A5E88B35A6B5722EFA2.description:
Appropriation in works of art has
potential legal and ethical implications that
scholars need to consider (e.g., scholars
must credit works that are used in visual/
audio sampling, parody, choreography).

036556B4DCB64D3D9E843195116D1F22.description:
Academic disciplines use specific
style guides for citing and attributing
sources (e.g., APA, MLA, Chicago, AMA).

158AE3788CDB4D2993524F9B27D8402B.description:
Quoted and paraphrased
material must be properly attributed,
credited, and cited following a style manual.
Quoting is using the exact words of others;
paraphrasing is restating an idea in one’s
own words.

B6C6C2AEA8C54567A2BB332F5517C2F0.description:
Source material should be
introduced, integrated, or embedded into
the text of an argument.

A1106663EF7D489D90D470C745A99045.description:
Plagiarism is a serious offense
that occurs when a person presents
another’s ideas or words as his or her
own. Plagiarism may be avoided by
acknowledging sources thoroughly and
accurately.

87D8581D913843FB9337F46282FE2D8D.description:
Accurate and ethical attribution
enhances one’s credibility.

9B76EE72C6B4491194E0FDBD7270CBEB.description:
Attributing knowledge
and ideas accurately and ethically,
using an appropriate citation style.

0D1DD76A8B2342BDB3262DAFBD6B7241.description:
Responsible participation in
the scholarly community requires
acknowledging and respecting the
prior findings and contributions of
others.

449DECF3A3834FBE9131F24830FA5F1A.description:
Commentary connects the
chosen evidence to the claim through
interpretation or inference, identifying
patterns, describing trends, and/or
explaining relationships (e.g., comparative,
causal, correlational).

AFEAD6CDACA843A292F6AB9C25F5AC26.description:
Providing insightful and
cogent commentary that links
evidence with claims.

6046C3E1D6A34439883373FDD88F846E.description:
The evidence selected and
attributed contributes to establishing the
credibility of one’s own argument.

9D5048D0F39D413E8A791A9DB703D495.description:
Evidence is strategically chosen
based on context, purpose, and audience.
Evidence may be used to align an argument
with authority; to define a concept, illustrate
a process, or clarify a statement; to set a
mood; to provide an example; to amplify or
qualify a point.

23EEDDE5F9084EF4B64A2E3DB94E7B54.description:
Evidence is used to support
the claims and reasoning of an argument.
Compelling evidence is sufficient, accurate,
relevant, current, and credible to support the
conclusion.

47565209C2B14058A30D9C5362415513.description:
Evidence can be collected
from print and nonprint sources (e.g.,
libraries, museums, archives), experts, or
data gathered in the field (e.g., interviews,
questionnaires, observations).

532465BF8D1A4BB3A8665F454DF59010.description:
Interpreting, using, and
synthesizing qualitative and/or
quantitative data/information from
various perspectives and sources
(e.g., primary, secondary, print,
nonprint) to develop and support
an argument.

8ED5D063FEEC4C19A653F5B1EC8483FD.description:
Scholars responsibly and
purposefully engage with the
evidence to develop a compelling
argument or aesthetic rationale.

B5E85E4F284E4E37880AD432D7D004FC.description:
Disciplines may be broadly or
narrowly defined. Disciplines can intersect or
be combined to provide new understandings
or perspectives.

FDAD0A4807164594935D42442EC78F19.description:
The different disciplines and
associated ways of knowing and valuing
information are discovered in part
through engaging with discipline-specific
foundational texts and works.

47730C9A623744858B0E717B9A1FEB97.description:
Scholars apply discipline-specific
terminology in the analysis of scholarly
works.

4AC46E2786924C05AE3F95D8BCA8F770.description:
Each discipline has its own
conventions and ways of knowing,
questioning, and communicating.

4BEC1566C88E4FE880852678C267F4DE.description:
Selecting and
consistently applying an
appropriate disciplinary or
interdisciplinary approach to
form a scholarly argument or
aesthetic rationale.

DCA94AC17CA64CC6ABA18DF55341091B.description:
An aesthetic rationale is an
argument in that it is a reasoned articulation
of specific formal and stylistic choices made
in the course of devising the artistic work.

E104082D21FA4980B983D458721EE632.description:
Scholars need to articulate
their choices, even when those choices
deliberately or inadvertently result in
ambiguity or lack of clarity.

9F2FB5A660D648328DCF212F4FA8A101.description:
Whether developing an
argument or conceptualizing an idea or work
of art, scholars thoughtfully choose and
implement a process aligned with the inquiry
or project goal.

4769E6BBD0554E9BA32225004029614E.description:
The same argument may be
organized, arranged, or supported in
multiple ways depending on audience and
context.

BDC04FB0A9104E299CFB2E06BBBA9AE6.description:
Claims and supporting evidence
are arranged (e.g., spatially, chronologically,
order of importance) to convey reasoning
and relationship (e.g., comparative, causal,
correlational).

8B577B2EA03D497B9D4F0146D8630BC1.description:
A line of reasoning is organized
based on the argument’s purpose (e.g., to
show causality, to evaluate, to define, to
propose a solution).

070E6A7A67924233A14F227C2CDFE768.description:
The logic and reasoning of an
argument may be deductive (claim followed
by evidence) or inductive (evidence leads to
a conclusion).

D332DB94E57F45B78B409E7771CE8621.description:
The line of reasoning is a clear,
logical path leading the audience through
the reasons to a conclusion.

6DBF3A0E0A2448A0956BAF8FE6AC7CC7.description:
Effective arguments may
acknowledge other arguments and/or
respond to them with counterarguments
(e.g., concession, refutation, rebuttal).

0EC653DD29904A23972FA53392D82FBB.description:
Qualifiers place limits on how far
a claim may be carried. Effective arguments
acknowledge these limits, increasing
credibility by reducing overgeneralization or
oversimplification.

ED4343BC1C04475A8B86C0EDEF0C03CC.description:
Effective arguments are
supported and unified by carefully chosen
and connected claims, reasons, and
evidence.

D789BE8C64F54821A21604ED670A8299.description:
Effective arguments use reason
and evidence to convey a perspective,
point of view, or some version of the truth
that is stated or implied in the thesis and/or
conclusion.

BCAF8446E66D4D209BFAD32AF5370D56.description:
Formulating a well-reasoned argument, taking the
complexities of the problem or
issue into consideration.

482D81E2E734475AAA2B7CFFA02C60CE.description:
Scholarly works convey
perspectives and demonstrate
effective reasoning that have been
selected for the intended audience,
purpose, and situation.

E8E620515B194C7BB47B3A93702036CD.description:
When evaluating
multiple perspectives or
arguments, consideration must be
given to how one’s own personal
biases and assumptions can
influence one’s judgment.

918DC333CA0B46ABA2CEE59995537543.description:
Critical thinkers are
aware that some arguments may
appeal to emotions, core values,
personal biases and assumptions,
and logic.

EE6D22C4F25A407E896825130C8CDF16.description:
Evaluating alternate,
opposing, or competing
perspectives or arguments, by
considering their implications and
limitations.

5E6A507A4FA94B9988D28F8BFC648478.description:
Not all arguments are
equal; some arguments are
more credible/valid than others.
Through evaluating others’
arguments, one’s own argument
can be situated within a larger
conversation.

1BEF2C9F76474768BE9C2AEDB6098BE4.description:
Some ideas/
perspectives are ambiguous or
not well defined. The process of
identification and interpretation
may not lead to a definitive answer.

B4E9556045264EB28969CF5757C4909B.description:
Perspectives are not
always oppositional; they may be
concurring, complementary, or
competing.

E40C9B7E37A1444CBA21E6557940D86D.description:
An individual’s
perspective is influenced by his or
her background (e.g., experiences,
culture, education), assumptions,
and worldview, as well as by
external sources.

80C084911F18468EB0A1C18C9C7D6776.description:
Identifying, comparing,
and interpreting multiple
perspectives on or arguments
about an issue.

B3606E12AFA042059BFF719B370B2659.description:
Different perspectives
often lead to competing and
alternative arguments. The
complexity of an issue emerges
when people bring these differing,
multiple perspectives to the
conversation.

A32988B94F4446DEA3344388EB599F6C.description:
Arguments are significant and
have real-world impact because they can
influence behavior (e.g., call one to action,
suggest logical next steps).

B50042FB2E8F4D6DB34A325764E444F0.description:
Evaluating potential
resolutions, conclusions, or
solutions to problems or issues
raised by an argument.

67358BBBAA104339AA712C1F921096D6.description:
The implications and
consequences of arguments may be
intended or unintended.

8BED90C18E46491797D4C36D21502474.description:
Connecting an argument
to broader issues by examining the
implications of the author’s claim.

8B9BB0104492443D848CA4348153AB3D.description:
Scholars analyze and evaluate
others’ studies and artistic works in terms
of internal coherence and alignment of the
purposes, goals, and methods of inquiry.

ECDA71475A744B4882CCA2DC7CE52099.description:
Evaluating and critiquing
others’ inquiries, studies, artistic
works, and/or perspectives.

F5CB0B7136DE432F890FCAC708CD0713.description:
Conclusions are contextual and
their validity must be affirmed, qualified, or
refuted.

51DE93196E3148D181652DA442C4CEFE.description:
Validity is most often achieved
when the presented evidence is aligned
with the conclusions. The strength of
an argument depends upon an author
acknowledging and/or considering the
limitations of his or her conclusions,
opposing views or perspectives, and/or his
or her own biases.

01C851E0BA8F45B283B4AE58E9D1208C.description:
An argument is valid when there
is logical alignment between the line of
reasoning and the conclusion.

C62C881EEA4E4FC4BF9DC53B6AF27924.description:
Evaluating the validity of
an argument.

C16778D7958546E8B30D42F5D24C9571.description:
Credibility is compromised
when authors fail to acknowledge and/or
consider the limitations of their conclusions,
opposing views or perspectives, and/or their
own biases.

EDA59C0F92114A6487548763FEDE0D0B.description:
Evidence may be used to identify
and explain relationships (comparative,
causal, or correlational) and/or patterns
and trends.

A0A3A98A7ECB44308D5642582F0B2EC5.description:
Writers appeal to (or possibly
manipulate) readers through a variety of
strategies and techniques (e.g., language,
authority, qualifiers, fallacies, emphasis).

EFB5EEE7583D444F8221F4D56086F299.description:
Authors strategically include
evidence to support their claims.

494D5B3964444506999408CDE7BDD437.description:
Writers use qualitative and/
or quantitative evidence (e.g., facts, data,
observations, predictions, analogies,
explanations, opinions) to support their
claims. Evidence has varying degrees of
validity.

AADC5FC210414D1C9BE05867E090ECD7.description:
An argument’s context (time and
purpose) and situation (in relation to other
arguments) inform its interpretation.

214937F2F40B459E9D2235236FD4E166.description:
Evaluating the relevance
and credibility of evidence used
to support an argument, taking
context into consideration.

46EB477F71814EF7904DE4556C460747.description:
Effective arguments acknowledge
other arguments and/or respond to them
with counterarguments (e.g., concession,
refutation, rebuttal).

D2D15C5C59CC47719F7D730614376EAB.description:
A lack of understanding of
the complexities of an argument (tone,
implications, limitations, nuance, context)
can lead to oversimplification and/or
generalization.

CFA62593C8C44184890974280C452299.description:
Inductive reasoning uses specific
observations and/or data points to identify
trends, make generalizations, and draw
conclusions. Deductive reasoning uses
broad facts or generalizations to generate
additional, more specific conclusions about
a phenomenon.

A424BF95EF1242A382AE5383DEFB647D.description:
An argument’s line of reasoning is
organized based on the argument’s purpose
(e.g., to show causality, to define, to propose
a solution).

8920C651889B4D6F895E3194E2DBF060.description:
Authors use reasons to support
their arguments. The line of reasoning is
composed of one or more claims justified
through evidence.

D2417DC5F798479EA151A9D3EA7046B5.description:
Explaining and analyzing
the logic and line of reasoning of
an argument.

4CEECDDD7F234B5EBCA958C2F73B35FC.description:
Authors choose evidence
to shape and support their
arguments. Individuals evaluate
the line of reasoning and evidence
to determine to what extent they
believe or accept an argument.

693A349C8967443DBCE435A832D527F7.description:
Artistic works (e.g., painting,
film, music, dance) convey a perspective.
Analysis of a work’s context, subject,
structure, style, and aesthetic is critical to
understanding its aims.

5A9AABD18761422ABCFE3BEEFBBE2DF9.description:
The main idea of an argument is
often expressed in the thesis statement,
claim, or conclusion, or implied throughout
a work.

ED2F493FF9014F1BB637425019649723.description:
Summarizing and
explaining a text’s main
idea or aim while avoiding
faulty generalizations and
oversimplification.

1737B4CFC1F646598BB83E4CEA299999.description:
Perspectives are shared through
written, spoken, visual, or performance texts.
A perspective includes the writer’s attitude/
tone regarding the subject and is expressed
through an argument.

0780EEC1C007470FAFC0E758697278CF.description:
Strategies active readers use
to make meaning from texts include
annotating, note-taking, highlighting, and
reading aloud.

1FE46EF001EE4EF7B77AA6B0D01B15EB.description:
Strategies active readers use
to preview and prioritize a written text
include skimming, scanning, rereading, and
questioning.

5AFE75E252CE4DF3B5631C6FBB44984A.description:
Reading critically means reading
closely to identify the main idea, tone,
assumptions, context, perspective, line of
reasoning, and evidence used.

58728F59A8DA49BD93851A72416A71FE.description:
Employing appropriate
reading strategies and reading
critically for a specific purpose.

821B33B1733C4CC184FA4E2BEF7E50BD.description:
Authors express their
ideas, perspectives, and/or
arguments through their works.
The first step in evaluating an
author’s perspective or argument
is to comprehend it. Such
comprehension requires reading,
viewing, listening, and thinking
critically.

C05866F213B14C76896FF24A7AD6829E.description:
There are copyright and patent
laws and guidelines that govern the use and
reproduction of others’ instruments, work,
personal information, and intellectual property.

D48A6A72D41947478778077849B30EA1.description:
There are laws, rules, and guidelines
that govern the conduct of researchers, in
particular when studies involve humans and
animals. Accordingly, scholars gain approval
to conduct research with humans through an
institutional review board (IRB).

9458A3DC212E4D4797AB431AC1E4FA84.description:
Scholars have ethical and moral
responsibilities when they conduct research.

C008187A20544B74896A410127B28A22.description:
Experts in the field may provide
guidance and/or discipline-specific knowledge
or perspective. Scholars must understand how
to seek advice while maintaining self-sufficiency.

9386720D1241498AA66A1AFC4BA65B29.description:
Scholars learn that setbacks are
inevitable; they need to focus on the essential
goals of the inquiry or project and be prepared
to try alternate approaches or look to other
disciplines in order to achieve them.

120F02B0B5CE4477A8EAA181E8C3EB69.description:
Scholars carefully plan methods of
inquiry, analysis, and other feasible research
activities, taking into account deadlines,
priorities, risks, setbacks, and the availability
of others.

112823BF1D3F4227BCA32D4DF16538FC.description:
Demonstrating
perseverance through setting
goals, managing time, and
working independently on a
long-term project.

2910225A94644801872C963FDB81F54A.description:
Scholars can combine qualitative
and quantitative data/information to triangulate
and corroborate trends, patterns, correlations,
and/or themes.

B0C467A35CDE411AB732A4C7E0029B2A.description:
Scholars often organize
and categorize (or code) data/information to
identify patterns or themes.

6038DE5DCE8E426CA899289DEB09E2D1.description:
Descriptive or inferential statistics
can be used to display and/or analyze data.

15504969FC0F41528B41586C72631715.description:
Scholars identify reasons for
choosing a sample of information, a population,
or artifacts and understand the limits of the
inferences or conclusions made based on the
sample chosen.

F364A6105DB04676B10A64D2A0A719A0.description:
Scholars analyze data or information
in a variety of ways appropriate to the inquiry.

37A745494B4C4A67B0613622B1E1B82A.description:
Based on the research question or
project goal, methods of data or information
collection may be qualitative (e.g., open-ended
survey questions, interviews, observational
notes, interpretation of texts); may be
quantitative (e.g., precise measurements,
modeling, using structured and validated data
collection instruments and procedures); or
could include a combination of both qualitative
and quantitative (mixed).

3A5D6FD4F85B4AA09D34B5EB518F1C62.description:
Artistic processes can include
elements of research methods as well as the
exploration and shaping/reshaping of media and
form through activities such as workshopping,
storyboarding, composing, choreographing,
staging, and model-making.

214D82486FE24DE89FF1E7F965F72F26.description:
Throughout the process of
determining scope and feasibility, the scholar
may, where appropriate, adjust the course of
inquiry and/or develop different tools, methods,
and processes.

1F051F90A56D4CF98B973DF10862E611.description:
Methods of inquiry may include
research methods (e.g., qualitative,
quantitative, or mixed) or artistic processes
(e.g., generating, conceptualizing, testing, and
then refining aesthetic approaches).

68AF06432A5B421996EF6EBBF0C45024.description:
Methods for data collection, analysis,
innovation, and/or interpretation should be
aligned with the research question/project goal.

EE24BE74FA8A4CF49EECADA252DEABF8.description:
Designing, planning,
and implementing a scholarly
inquiry.

155FC519795146B49B22B373FE52BE2E.description:
The way the problem is posed, situated,
framed, or contextualized will guide the inquiry
process and influence the type of information
needed and appropriate method of gathering it.

13338A8C606C4C778B8566E96495619B.description:
Identifying the
information needed for the
context of the inquiry

27E3686051CB49008521CBFA4CDFE656.description:
There are multiple ways to
investigate questions, problems,
and issues. Methods should be
aligned with the purpose of the
inquiry.

C6BE91A1303C47F79965C0A8C083CC6A.description:
When gathering data on individuals’
behaviors, attitudes, and preferences, the
accuracy and validity of such data depends
on the honesty, memory, and reliability of the
respondents and/or observers as well as the
design of the data collection instrument.

A4B4AD45E64A496BB3F60DA4C360311E.description:
Determining the credibility of a
source requires considering and evaluating
the reputation and credentials of the author,
publisher, site owner, and/or sponsor;
understanding and evaluating the author’s
perspective and research methods; and
considering how others respond to their work.
Scholarly articles are often peer-reviewed,
meaning the research has been reviewed and
accepted by disciplinary experts.

4E3A95113AAE46D887C5EF5F33599E5F.description:
Credibility of evidence depends on
use of sources and data that are relevant and
reliable (current, authoritative).

638D2A1425794A048E959C3EF570D353.description:
The scope and purpose of one’s
research and the credibility of sources affects
the generalizability and the reliability of the
conclusions.

5392B39DBD9044F7A003CA6DF17E44CA.description:
Evaluating the
relevance and credibility of the
source of information and data
in relation to the inquiry.

86B73CB03DC1431D849D93B1C9E74509.description:
The relevance and
credibility of the source of
information is determined by
the context of its use.

218A7C8DCF39428080FEBA110059FA9D.description:
Software and online tools (e.g.,
SurveyMonkey, SPSS) can be used to survey
participants and analyze large data sets.

F287F8B54F024BC98FE0A1B596F4D87E.description:
Software (e.g., Microsoft Word,
EndNote) and online tools (e.g., citation
generators, WorldCat) are used by scholars
to manage and catalog sources and produce
bibliographies.

0B13CCAD6F4C4A0FA1D8D7A059DD3AB1.description:
Social media may be used as
a potential source of information, but an
understanding of its limitations is necessary to
maintain credibility.

1548C853D6BF4502877471D6CBDBCB57.description:
Consulting the bibliographies of
other sources may provide additional ideas or
resources.

5951A2E1BA5A417C870835B751CF0FC2.description:
Advanced search tools, Boolean logic,
and key words allow scholars to refine, focus,
and/or limit their searches based on a variety of
factors (e.g., date, peer-review status, type of
publication).

AC4A7C1A4DEC447DAEAAF67A95B1778E.description:
Online databases (e.g., EBSCO,
ProQuest, JSTOR, Google Scholar) and libraries
catalog and house secondary and some primary
sources.

31EF0E2CC62D471AAA9E10C5C46F49B5.description:
Information used to address a
problem may come from various secondary
sources (e.g., articles, other studies, analyses,
reports) and/or primary sources (e.g., original
texts and works, material culture, or personally
collected data such as from experiments,
surveys, questionnaires, interviews,
observations, personal narratives).

4E80DDB732A84A80939C25873741F09F.description:
Accessing and
managing information using
effective strategies.

5760A753BDD44935B4FB273F33B538D7.description:
The investigative process is
aided by the effective organization,
management, and selection
of resources and information.
Appropriate technologies and
tools enable the scholar to become
more efficient, productive, and
credible.

8A9EDAFC156B4364875E895CA6631AC8.description:
Inquiry confirms or challenges one’s
existing understandings, assumptions, beliefs,
and/or knowledge.

AB1CCF01B01E45CAB13F47F0388CE2B0.description:
A variety of strategies (e.g.,
brainstorming, concept mapping, prewriting,
exploration of space, drafting) can be used to
illustrate, organize, and connect ideas.

0B5F9B89F2BD4687960FF990FEFFA488.description:
Understanding comes not only
through collection of information but also from a
variety of other factors (e.g., experience, external
sources, cultural context, assumptions).

213601C93B9B49C3AE2D5C0D6600A115.description:
Retrieving,
questioning, organizing, and
using prior knowledge about a
topic.

0A03949A0E2C4815B701ADF29108DA85.description:
Strengthening
understanding of a concept or
issue requires questioning existing
ideas, using what is known to
discover what is not known, and
making connections to prior
knowledge.

88E78AEC70894F8C94484C436DBE7B84.description:
A research question/project goal
often requires multiple revisions to ensure it is
appropriate in terms of scope and feasibility
(time, resources).

7208EDD0905E4AEF9A125AE625362DCC.description:
A research question/project goal
emerges from the scholar’s purpose (i.e., to
explore, explain, and create).

26544E3008BC4EECAA82CC5CCF992270.description:
Developing and
revising a focused research
question/project goal.

FF5F37C25F1B475BB28E127D220031CA.description:
Scholarly inquiry should be situated
within a broader understanding of the scholarly
community and of importance and relevance to
that community.

33881E84E2C04FD08F46B7997F434627.description:
The purpose of scholarly inquiry
is to address various kinds of problems (e.g.,
practical, theoretical, interpretive, aesthetic)
and/or corroborate, challenge, or extend an
existing idea.

CCCC569DA4744C3287527DF1EDAA188F.description:
Articulating the
purpose and significance
of the scholarly inquiry.

F17EFBFDAE1742F0B828FC70C48554CC.description:
Inquiry allows for the discovery of
connections that can increase curiosity or
understanding and lead to further questions.

008DF8187821437AAC2ABA8769444883.description:
The inquiry process involves
exploring the knowledge base associated
with the topic of interest, including a variety
of perspectives, and adjusting the scope of
the topic to the parameters, requirements, and
resources available for the project.

CCE4614A6428450BA68B8E70BD9F9EFC.description:
Topics of inquiry may come from
personal interest, passion for a discipline/field,
desire to better understand a topic, or desire to
address an issue in the world.

F8BE8ED746BB4DF6BADAA95DA3184557.description:
The inquiry process allows one to
draw upon curiosity and imagination to engage
with ideas or explore approaches to complex
issues.

E3BECA6F4538445284C1B9739DB1CE7C.description:
Effective research questions lead
to an examination taking into account the
complexity of a problem or issue.

32E248B3926640019AAF7194B1480B89.description:
Posing questions
and seeking out answers that
reflect multiple, divergent, or
contradictory perspectives.

42232B5D880F44CFAF14CB1DC85C33D1.description:
Examining the perspectives and ideas
of others often leads to questions for further
investigation. Inquiry begins with narrowing
scope of interest, identifying a problem or issue
and its origins within that scope, and situating
the problem or issue in a larger context.

171B105034C1406EB7F56A08E7AE8DAC.description:
Contextualizing and
identifying the complexities of
a problem or issue.

BBD9277806CD42A595435693CA4EE71D.description:
Personal interest and
intellectual curiosity inspire
investigation of topics or
issues that may or may not
be clearly defined. A wellcrafted investigation explores
the complexity of an issue or
topic. Further inquiry can lead
to unexpected conclusions,
resolutions, innovations, or
solutions.
